plist.p: Welcome to the Q2 2012 Walmart de México SAB de CV Walmex Earnings Conference call. My name is Christine and I'll be your operator for today's call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode.

The date of this call is July 23, 2012. Before we start, let me remind you that this call is property of Walmart de México SAB de CV. And it is intended for the use of the company's shareholders and the investment community. It should not be reproduced in any way.

This call may contain certain references concerning Walmart de México SAB de CV's future performance that should be considered as good faith estimates made by the company. These references only reflect management expectations and are based upon currently available data. Actual results are always subject to future events, risk, and uncertainties, which could materially impact the company's actual performance.
Good afternoon, everyone and thanks for joining us today for Walmart de México Centroamérica earnings call to review the second quarter of the year 2012.

Here with me is Scot Rank, our Chief Executive Officer for Walmart de México Centroamérica. I'm glad to report an overall good quarter driven by stability improvement in Mexico. I will turn it over to Scot to go over the results.

Thanks, Rafael and good afternoon to everyone. In the second quarter, Mexico delivered solid profitability with improvements in gross margin and a strong discipline in expenses. Let's take a closer look at some of the key performance metrics for the quarter in Mexico.

Total sales for Mexico grew 10.3% while comparable store sales increased 3%. Comparable store sales were below our expectations, so we are reinforcing the four key strategies to drive same store sales that we established at the beginning of the year.

These strategies are: one, price leadership, we're investing in prices and overall price gaps are in line with our objectives. Two, win in traffic departments, we had mixed performance, so we are reinforcing the departments that are not performing according to our expectation. Three, modular execution, modulars need to be a greater source in growing sales. And four, supply, we need to improve inventory management and maximize product availability on the shelf.

We had stock outs in May that we corrected in June, but we ended the month with high levels of inventories based on a higher sales expectation. Our merchandising team is working with our replenishment and logistics teams to ensure we have a consistent efficient flow of merchandise.

Gross profit in Mexico increased 12%, improving margins by 40 basis points compared to last year. Improvement was mainly driven by lower shrink and better negotiations with suppliers. Our company leveraged operating expenses this quarter. Last year, we had challenging second quarter in terms of expenses as a result of anticipated investments. While this quarter, we not only reverted that trend, but we are delivering on our productivity initiatives and reducing cost per average square meter by 2.3%.

We had good performance in key items such as associate productivity. The bank continues to show significant progress, supplier and consumer loans doubled, and we reached 419,000 credit card, 1.7 times what we had a year ago. Deposits amounted to MX$3.8 billion, 2.4 times the amount that we had at the end of the second quarter last year.
As a result of gross margin improvement and good expense control on our retail business in Mexico, EBITDA increased by 14.8%, which nicely compares with the 10.3% increase in sale.
Banco Walmart also delivered improvements at EBITDA level, so EBITDA for Mexico including retail and bank increased by 16.3%.

Overall, we are pleased with Mexico's profitability with operating income and EBITDA growing faster than sales. Total income for Mexico increased 10.4% or MX$7.9 billion to MX$84.3 billion for the quarter.

Gross margin grew 12.4% higher than sales growth and expenses grew 9%. I believe we have set the groundwork for the rest of the year, and our ability to continually find ways to reduce operating expenses and improve productivity means we can continue to invest in price leadership. Second quarter EBITDA grew 16.3% to MX$8.5 billion.

Now, let's review highlights for our operation in Central America. There are 606 stores converted into Walmart Systems and 20 stores in El Salvador that remain to be converted. With regards to distribution centers, we have converted Costa Rica and Nicaragua. We will finish integrating distribution systems by mid-2013.

We are also in the process of implementing supporting systems. These are key tools that provide visibility and that together with the training programs we're putting into practice for our merchants, will allow us to start taking advantage of the level of information that Walmart Systems provide.

Without effective inventory management, we missed sales and added costs that showed up in markdowns. The leadership team in Central America is taking the strategic steps to strengthen the consistency of our execution to reach our long-term goals.

In Central America, overall sales increased 7.5% and comp sales were up 0.4% on a constant currency basis. We remain committed to growth in Central America. EDLP and item merchandising drive comp sales growth and new stores drive total sales growth.

During the second quarter, we reduced inventory levels in Central America by 12%. This was achieved via aggressive markdowns that impacted gross margin. We continue to work on the underlying processes required to deliver sustainable, solid inventory management in Central America. The level of inventory that we need to markdown remains high and so we expect this negative trend in gross margin to continue during the third quarter of the year.

Central America's second quarter total income was MX$14.2 billion, MX$2.6 billion more than last year. This represents a 22.9% increase in peso terms or a 7.5% increase on a constant currency basis. Gross margin was down 110 basis points as a result of pricing investments and markdowns to lower inventory levels.

For the second quarter, expenses grew at a slower rate than sales, resulting in 30 basis points of leverage. EBITDA was down 18.7% on a constant currency basis, as a result of the decline in gross margin. We recognize that Central America will take time to improve, but we feel confident about our business strategies and our ability to drive better results from the business.
And with that, I'll ask Rafael to provide consolidated results and more of the financial details. Rafael?

Our consolidated total income for the quarter increased 12%. As you know, one of our key financial metrics is to grow EBITDA faster than sales growth. EBITDA for the second quarter of this year grew 14.7%, which exceeded our sales growth of 12%. We achieved this objective by increasing gross margin more than sales in Mexico and a disciplined expense management in both Mexico and Central America. Our company will remain very focused on expense leverage.

Our financial position remains very strong. As of the second quarter of the year 2012, our cash position amounted to approximately MX$20 billion, 25% more than last year. Year-to-date, we have invested MX$5 billion in fixed assets, and returned MX$9.7 billion to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases.

Inventories increased 26% versus last year as a result of 361 new stores opened during the last 12 months, while accounts payable to suppliers increased 24%. Accounts receivable from the Banco Walmart are fully funded by deposits from customers.

Our earnings performance continues to translate into strong cash generation. Over the last 12 months to June, we generated (9:13) from our operations, plus MX$581 million from negative working capital requirements. Our priority for cash remain growth and return to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. We invested MX$16.3 billion in fixed assets, paid dividends in cash for MX$9.6 billion, repurchased company shares for MX$3.3 billion and paid taxes for MX$8.3 billion.

Year-to-date, we have added a total of 1.5 million square feet through 111 units, 104 of them in Mexico and 7 in Central America. We opened 70 discount stores, 26 Bodegas, 3 Walmarts, 6 Sam's, 2 Supermarkets, 2 Suburbias and 2 restaurants.
Now, I will turn it back to Scot to make some additional comments.

I remind you that Walmart de México y Centroamérica is participating in an independent investigation in possible corrupt practices, initiated by the audit committee of Walmart Stores, Inc., and revisions into similar matters by the competent authorities in Mexico.
Our complete statement can be accessed at Walmart Investor Relations website as part of the second quarter 2012 financial information to the Mexican Stock Exchange.

With the objective of becoming a world-class company in upholding the highest standards of ethical behavior and ensuring that its operations abide by all applicable laws and regulations, the company has decided to reinforce its organizational structure and beginning July 16, 2012, Javier Soní Ocampo joins Walmart de México Centroamérica as Chief Compliance and Administrative Officer and Executive Vice President.

Until June 30, 2012, he was Territorial Director Partner of Pricewaterhouse Coopers, where he had a successful career since 1971. Javier, who is a public accountant, has as well been part of the different boards of directors, committees, treasury offices as well as a member of the Mexican Institute of Public Accountants and Finance Executives. An important part of his team will be the, as well, new Vice Presidency of Compliance.

Furthermore, at the end of August, Adriana Velázquez Villaseñor will integrate into the company as Anti-corruption Director, FCPA, in substitution of Jeff Davis, reporting directly to Tom Gean, Global FCPA Compliance Officer of Walmart Stores.
With this, we are ending our conference call, and I remind you that we will be available to receive calls with questions that you may have. Thank you once again.
Thank you, ladies and gentlemen. This concludes today's conference. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect.
